episodes.title: The day my faith imploded
episodes.description:
A little over a year ago, researching certain details about the bible book of Daniel led me to completely re-examine my beliefs about god, the bible, and the Watchtower/Jehovah church. I would have liked to make this video a bit shorter, but I didn't want to leave anything out either.

Daniel's Prophecy book PDF: http://da-ip.getmyip.com:8080/pdf/Publications Without Pictures/1999, 2006 - Pay Attention to Daniel's Prophecy! - book.pdf (page 177 is particularly relevant)
The small horn from Chapter 7: http://photos1.blogger.com/blogger/1808/1427/1600/scan0001.0.jpg

episodes.title: Jehovah's Witness Appeal Committee hidden camera recording 2016-01-20
episodes.description:
An appeal committee, to review the decision to have me disfellowshipped (i.e. shunned) for disagreeing with church leadership. 

Sadly, the battery on my hidden camera failed me about 40 minutes in, but not surprisingly, the decision to disfellowship was upheld. 

Judicial Committee Part 1: https://youtu.be/bkbO_lYlPRQ
Judicial Committee Part 2: https://youtu.be/mB-KweFxBRc

When I stopped believing in the Organization, I knew that the only likely outcomes were either disfellowshipping, or spending the rest of my life pretending to be something I'm not, as though I were ashamed of simple logic and skepticism. I went to this meeting, not to avoid being disfellowshipped, but to challenge the elders to justify their immoral actions, and to expose the things they do in secret to the harsh light of day.

Please excuse the poor camera work, the camera was hidden in my shirt pocket.

episodes.title: Jehovah's Witness judicial committee hidden camera recording 2016-01-10 PART 2
episodes.description:
Part 2 of 2

This is what happens when a Jehovah's Witness gets caught not believing in the stories that he was raised with. They call this apostasy, which in their view, includes holding or sharing any viewpoints contrary to what is taught by the Organization. The accusation is examined by a committee of at least 3 elders, who meet with the accused alone and in secret to provide congregational discipline. Failure to attend this meeting makes conviction virtually automatic.

The punishment for apostasy (among many other perceived sins) is what they call disfellowshipping, that is, removal of said person from the congregation. The moment one is removed from the congregation, all Jehovah's Witnesses, which usually includes all the person's closest friends and immediate family, are explicitly forbidden to speak to that person. The only way to reverse this is by repenting, re-committing oneself to the service of the Organization, and begging the Elders to let you back in. This humiliating reinstatement process usually lasts at least a year.

When I stopped believing in the Organization, I knew that the only likely outcomes were either disfellowshipping, or spending the rest of my life pretending to be something I'm not, as though I were ashamed of simple logic and skepticism. I went to this meeting, not to avoid being disfellowshipped, but to challenge the elders to justify their immoral actions, and to expose the things they do in secret to the harsh light of day.

Please excuse the poor camera work, the camera was hidden in my shirt pocket.

Part 1: https://youtu.be/bkbO_lYlPRQ
Appeal Committee meeting: https://youtu.be/7nFlfCHtScA
